Politics Title: Trump lawyers say they will not fight subpoena for Don Jr 
 Text: The White House is fighting with the Senate Judiciary Committee to keep its request for documents related to Donald Trump's son and son-in-law during their congressional testimony from being released. 
 
 A court filing Saturday says that responding to a subpoena, the committee believes it would be "irreparable" damage if the president agreed to return all materials requested. It also argues in part that releasing some of those records could have adverse effects on Mueller's investigation. 
 
 In response to an agreement reached between President Donald Trump Jr. and special counsel Robert Mueller, the president's legal team has filed papers arguing against release by saying the material sought includes information about a June 2016 meeting at Trump Tower involving top campaign officials including his eldest son.

Science Title: A new study shows that humans and chimpanzees can use both the left hand and right foot to detect a difference between two objects as small as one millimeter. 
 Text: The research was conducted by [University of Oxford scientists](here). It involved measuring how different things looked depending on their size. This is important for people who have trouble with distinguishing between tiny things. For example, if you were in front of something made out of paper, but it appeared much larger than your hand, then yes, you'd be able to tell enough differences from visual cues alone to place them on equal footing. But this doesn't mean we should assume all animals will do this. If anything, it's probably better to think about it like this: Humans are really good at estimating distances based solely off our sense of sight.

Science Title: The most effective way to prevent malaria is for people living in poor countries not only to avoid mosquito bites but also to wash their clothes after using the toilet, according to a study 
 Text: Malaria can be controlled by many methods such as wearing insect repellent or insecticide-treated bed nets. However these are usually expensive and hard to get hold of so they have little effect. A new method has been developed that could make this an easier task, which reduces the cost and increases effectiveness. It involves washing your hands before you enter the toilet with soap containing antimalarial drugs. This results in fewer mosquito bites. 
 Source: [Scientific American](sciencebasedmedicine.org/content/6/3/439.full)
